entry.title: Biological Physics
entry.content:
Intro-Biomolecules

Statistical-Physics-Basics

Basics

Microstate:
M particles, N levels: $\Omega = M^N$
Macrostate:
Histogram of the number of particles per energy level
Macrostate{3, 1, 5}:

  • 3 particles are in level 1
  • 1 particle is in level 2
  • 5 particles are in level 3

Fundamental concept of statistical Physics

  • Describe a system only as a MACROSTATE = Histogram
  • It is not relevant which individual particle is in what level
  • Compared to the exact description of a system (MICROSTATE), information is lost. A histogram contains LESS information than the data set that generated it
  • Cannot construct the exact(MICROSTATE) of a system from the MACROSTATE because the MACROSTATE is just a distribution
  • The amount of the missing information is measureed by the statistical weight $\Omega$ of the Macrostate, or $\ln(\Omega)$

Stastical weight of a macrostate $\Omega$

How many microstates belong to the macrostate
eg: {2,0,0,1,0} has 3 microstates

$\Omega = N!$(æ‰€æœ‰ç²’å­èƒ½é‡å‡ä¸ç›¸åŒ)

Degeneracy

${1,0,0,2}: \Omega = rac{3!}{2!}$

Entropy

$S = k_B \ln \Omega, \Omega = rac{N!}{n_0!n_1!\cdots}$

Stirlingâ€™s theorem
$$N! \approx rac{N^N}{e^N}\sqrt{2\pi N}$$
$$\ln N! \approx N \ln N -N$$

Entropy S is a property of a macrostate of a system, gives the level of disorder of that macrostate

Boltzman-Free-Energy

Boltzman

$\ln \Omega = \ln rac{N!}{\prod_{i}n_i!} = N\ln N - \sum_{i}(n_i\ln n_i)$
Maximum of entropy occurs for $dS = d(k_B \ln \Omega)=0$
$$d\ln\Omega=-\sum_{i}\ln n_i dn_i=0$$
$\sum_i n_i = N, \sum_i dn_i=0$
Use Lagrangeâ€™s method of undertimined multipliers: $n_i = rac{N}{M}$

Microcanonical ensemble

$$\sum_i \epsilon_in_i = E$$
$n_i = Ae^{- eta\epsilon_i},A = e^{-\lambda}$
$n_i = N rac{e^{- eta\epsilon_i}}{\sum_ie^{- eta\epsilon_i}}$
$p_i = rac{e^{- eta\epsilon_i}}{\sum_ie^{- eta\epsilon_i}}$
$Z = \sum_{i=1}^{M}e^{- eta\epsilon_i}$
$T=0, eta = \infty,p_1=1,p_{i\geq 2}=0$
$T=\infty, eta=0,p_i = rac{1}{M}$
$E = \sum_i \epsilon_in_i=N\sum_i\epsilon_ip_i= rac{N}{Z}\sum_i\epsilon_ie^{- eta\epsilon_i}=-N rac{\partial\ln Z}{\partial eta}$

Constant total energy of system depends on temperature

Connection

$dQ=TdS$
$$E=U=\sum_i\epsilon_in_i$$
$$dU = \sum_i\epsilon_idn_i+\sum_in_id\epsilon_i$$
å› ä¸º$\ln \Omega$é‡Œé¢æœ‰$dn_i$ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ç¬¬ä¸€é¡¹æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯$dQ$ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒé¡¹æ˜¯$dW$

Ensembles

$$S_{AB}=S_A+S_B$$

çœ‹çœ‹ä¸‹é¢ä¸‰ä¸ªå®šä¹‰æ€ä¹ˆæ¨çš„

Temperature definition

$$ rac{1}{T}\equiv rac{\partial S}{\partial E}$$

Pressure definition

$$ rac{P}{T}=( rac{\partial S}{\partial V})_E$$

Chemical potential definition

$$ rac{\mu}{T}=-( rac{\partial S}{\partial N})_{E,V}$$

Free energy

çœ‹pptè¿˜æœ‰tutorialå§

Partition Function

Degeneracy

$Z=e^{- eta\epsilon_1}+2e^{- eta\epsilon_2}$

In equilibrium, E,S and F are connected t Z by simple equations

$S= rac{E}{T}+Nk\ln Z$
$F =E-TS$
$S=Nk(\ln Z +T rac{\ln Z}{\partial T})$

Partition function of the system

$Z_N=Z^N$
$Z_N=\sum_ie^{- eta E_i}$

Boltzmann Distribution derivation by system

$p_i= rac{1}{Z_N}e^{- eta\epsilon_i}$

Mixing-Osmosis

Mixing Entropy and dilute solutions

Lattice models: $N=N_W+N_S$

Entropy of Mixing

Polymer solutions-Mixing entropy

Polymer solutions

Entropy of mixing: $\Delta S_{mix}=-k(A\ln rac{A}{A+B}+B\ln rac{B}{A+B})$

çœ‹pptè¿˜æœ‰tutorialå§

Osmosis

Entropy of mixing: $\Delta S_{mix}=-k(N_S\ln rac{N_S}{N_S+N_W}+N_W\ln rac{N_W}{N_S+N_W})\approx -k(N_S\ln rac{N_S}{N_W}-N_S)$

Solvation energy = contribution per solute molecule multiplied by the total number of such molecules.
$$dU=\epsilon_s dn_s$$
First law of thermodynamics
$\epsilon_sdN_s+\mu_W^0dN_W=TdS+\mu_SdN_S+\mu_WdN_W$
åˆ†åˆ«ä»¤$dN_S,dN_W=0$, æœ‰$\mu_W=\dots, \mu_S = \dots$
ä½¿ç”¨$\Delta S_{mix}$å¾—åˆ°æ‰€éœ€åå¯¼
æœ€åå¾—åˆ°ï¼š$\mu_S=\epsilon_S+kT\ln rac{n_S}{n_W}$
$$\mu_S=\mu_0+kT\ln rac{c}{c_0},\enspace c = rac{n_S}{V},\enspace c_0= rac{n_W}{V}$$

Osmotic Pressure

$$\Delta P=cRT$$
$R = k_BN_A$
if equation contains kB, quantities relate to one particle, otherwise relate to one mole

$$\Delta P=cRT,\enspace c(mol/L)$$

$$\Delta P=ck_BT,\enspace c(ä¸ª/m^3)$$

Revere Osmosis

çœ‹tutorialå§

5. Binding

5.1 Equilibria Binding

Ligand-Receptor Binding

è¦çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹pptå’Œtutorialï¼Œæ¨$p_{bound}$
Hill function

Reactions

$$K_{eq} \equiv \prod_i c_{i-eq}^{\upsilon_i}$$

$\Delta G = \sum_i\upsilon_i\mu_i$
$\mu = \mu_0+kT\ln rac{c}{c_0}$
$\Delta G =0$
$$\Delta G_0=-k_BT\ln K_{eq}$$

$$\Delta G=k_BT\ln rac{K}{K_{eq}}$$

5.2 Protein folding

å…¨æ˜¯å™è¿°ï¼Œçœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹pptï¼Œä¸çœ‹ä¹Ÿæ²¡é—®é¢˜

6. Grand-canonical-cooperativity

6.1 Gibbs-Ensemble

finding a given state of the system(charaterized by an energy $E_A$ and nuber of particles $N_A$ is proportional to the number of states available to the reservoir $R$) when the system is in this state

$$p_A = rac{Z}{e^{- eta(E_A-\mu N_A)}}$$
$$Z=\sum_ie^{- eta (E_i-\mu N_i)}$$

çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorialï¼Œæ€ä¹ˆç”¨å…¬å¼

6.2 Cooperativity

ä½¿ç”¨ä¸ŠèŠ‚å…¬å¼ï¼Œçœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorialï¼Œæ€ä¹ˆç”¨å…¬å¼

7. Aminoacids-pKa-ATP-Phosphorylation

7.1 Aminoacids-pKa

Proteins, chirality, diversity, peptide bond formation, basic protein structure, from primary to quaternary structure, disease
$K_W=[OH^-][H_3O^+],pH$
$pK_a=pH-\lg rac{[A^-]}{[AH]}$
å¾—ï¼š$ rac{[A^-]}{AH}=\dots$
$$p(A^-)= rac{1}{1+10^(pK_a-pH)}$$

$$p(HA)= rac{1}{1+10^(pH-pK_a)}$$

7.2 ATP

çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorial ATPæ€ä¹ˆç®—

7.3 Phosphorylation

çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorial ATPæ€ä¹ˆç®—

8. Diffusion

8.1 Mean Variance SEM

mean: $\overline{x}= rac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}x_i=\sum_ip_ix_i=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}xp(x)dx$
$\sigma:$ ä¸‰ç§å½¢å¼

æ¨ä¸€ä¸‹pptæ¦‚ç‡å…¬å¼ï¼Ÿ

8.2 Diffusion

Divergence theorem: $\int_V abla \cdot \mathbf EdV =\oiiint \mathbf E\cdot d\mathbf A$
Continuity equation: $ abla\cdot\mathbf j(\mathbf r,t)=- rac{\partial ho(\mathbf r,t)}{\partial t}$
Flux: $\mathbf j \equiv rac{Substance}{Area imes Time} = ho \mathbf v$
Fickâ€™s First Law:
$$j = -D rac{d ho}{dx},\enspace \mathbf j=-D abla ho$$

Fickâ€™s Second Law:
$$ rac{\partial ho}{\partial t}=D abla^2 ho$$
Solution:
$$ ho(x,t)= rac{ ho_0}{\sqrt{4\pi Dt}}e^{- rac{(x-x_0)^2}{4Dt}}$$

$$ ho(\mathbf r,t)= rac{ ho_0}{\sqrt{4\pi Dt}}e^{- rac{(\mathbf r-\mathbf r_0)^2}{4Dt}}$$
mean: $\overline{x}(t)=0$
variance: $\sigma_x^2=2Dt$

Brownain motion microscopic model: Random walk

$\overline{X}=0$
But what counts is not the mean position, but the spread
$\sigma_x^2=N(\overline{x^2}-\overline{x}^2)=N\overline{x^2}=Nl^2=N\overline{v}l au=\overline{v}lt$
åˆï¼š$\sigma _x^2(t)=2Dt$
$D= rac{1}{2}\overline{v}l$
Different equations for different situations are in ppt

$$x = \sigma_x = \sqrt{2D}\sqrt{t}$$

Diffusion with external forces

$v_D=\mu F= rac{1}{\gamma}mg$
Down-flux: $j_1=\mu mg ho$
Up-flux: $j_2=-D rac{d ho}{dh}$
$j_1=j_2$
$$ ho(h)= ho_0e^(- rac{\mu mg}{D}h)$$

Compared to Boltzman distribution:
$$ ho(h)= ho_0e^{- eta mgh},\enspace E=mgh$$

Einstein Relation:
$$D=\mu kT$$

Special case for Stokeâ€™s Law

Frictional force (drag force) exerted on spherical objects with very small Reynolds numbers (e.g., very small particles)in a continuous viscous fluid
Stokeâ€™s Law:
$$F=6\pi R\eta v,\enspace \mu= rac{v}{F}$$

$$D = rac{kT}{6\pi R\eta}$$

Flux with external force: $\mathbf{j}=-D abla ho +\mu F ho$
Diffusion equation with external force: $ rac{\partial ho}{\partial T}=D abla^2 ho-\mu F abla ho$

9. Electro

9.1 Poission-Boltzmann

Electronics for Salty Solutions

Magnetic fields play (almost) no role
$$ abla \cdot\mathbf{E}(\mathbf{r})= rac{ ho(\mathbf{r})}{\varepsilon_0}$$
Poissonâ€™s equation: $ abla^2\Phi(\mathbf{r})=- rac{ ho(\mathbf{r})}{\varepsilon_0}$
Laplaceâ€™s equation: $ abla^2 \Phi(\mathbf{r})=0$

$p_{Ion}(\mathbf{r})\propto e^{- eta E(\mathbf{r})}, \enspace E(\mathbf{r})=q\Phi(\mathbf{r})$
Charge density of the ion cloud:
$$ ho_i(\mathbf{r})=q_in_i^{\infty}e^{- eta q_i\Phi(\mathbf{r})}$$

total charge density:
$$ ho_{Ions}(\mathbf{r})=\sum_iq_in_i^{\infty}e^{- eta q_i\Phi(\mathbf{r})}$$

Poisson-Boltzman equation
$$ abla^2\Phi(\mathbf{r})=- rac{e}{\varepsilon}\sum_{i=1}^nz_ic_{i,\infty}e^{- eta z_ie\Phi(\mathbf{r})}- rac{ ho(\mathbf{r})}{\varepsilon}$$

çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorial

9.2 Debye-Huckel theory

Bjerrum length

Balance the ekectrostatic interaction energy:
$$ rac{e^2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0Dl_B}=k_BT$$

$$l_B= rac{e^2}{4\pi\varepsilon_0Dk_BT}$$

Debye-Huckel theory

Debye-Huckle equation:
$$ abla^2\Phi(\mathbf{r})= rac{e^2 eta}{\varepsilon}(\sum_iz_i^2n_i^{\infty})\Phi(\mathbf{r})$$

Debye length
$$\lambda_D=( rac{\varepsilon k_BT}{e^2\sum_iz_i^2n_i^{\infty}})^{ rac{1}{2}}$$

Ionic strength
$$I\equiv rac{1}{2}\sum_iz_i^2n_i^{\infty}$$

$$ abla^2\Phi(\mathbf{r})= rac{1}{\lambda_D^2}\Phi(\mathbf{r})$$

entry.title: QFTå’ŒQMçš„åŒºåˆ«
entry.content:
Differences between QFT and QM

1. Theoretical Framework and Scope

  • QM
    • Scopeï¼šPrimarily used to study the behavior of microscopic particles such as electrons, protons, and atoms.
    • Objects of Descriptionï¼šIndividual particlesâ€™ motion, energy, wave functions, etc.
    • Fundamental Principlesï¼šBased on SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s equation, the probabilistic interpretation of the wave function, and the uncertainty principle.
  • QFT
    • Scopeï¼š Used to describe interactions between particles, especially in high-energy physics, addressing fundamental particles and forces.
    • Objects of Descriptionï¼šThe relationship between fields and particles, where particles are seen as excitations of the underlying fields.
    • Fundamental PrinciplesBased on the quantization of fields, covering electromagnetic fields, strong interactions, weak interactions, etc.

2. Mathematical Tools and Methods

  • QM
    • Uses wave functions (or state vectors) to describe particle states.
    • Employs SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s equation or Heisenbergâ€™s matrix mechanics to describe the evolution of particles.
  • QFT
    • Utilizes field operators($\Psi(\boldsymbol{r})$) to describe the quantum states of fields.
    • Applies Lagrangians, Hamiltonians, and path integrals to describe the evolution and interactions of fields.

3. Concept of Particles and Fields

  • QM
    • Particles are described by the probability density of wave functions, exhibiting wave-particle duality.
    • Focuses on the motion, energy states, and evolution of particlesâ€™ wave functions.
  • QFT
    • Particles are described as excitations of quantum fields, e.g., the electron fieldâ€™s quantum excitations are electrons.
    • Emphasizes the quantization of fields, where different types of fields correspond to different particles.

4. Relativity

  • QM
    • Generally deals with non-relativistic cases, where particlesâ€™ velocities are much less than the speed of light.
    • Relativistic quantum mechanics (like the Dirac equation) is an extension but does not fully encompass relativistic effects.
  • QFT
    • Fully compatible with relativity, handling relativistic particles and interactions at high energies.
    • For example, Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) describes electromagnetic interactions within a relativistic quantum field framework.

5. Application Areas

  • QM
    • Mainly applied in atomic physics, molecular physics, condensed matter physics, quantum information, etc.
    • Describes the electronic structure and energy levels within atoms, molecules, and solids.
  • QFT
    • Primarily applied in high-energy physics, particle physics, and cosmology.
    • Describes the fundamental particles and forces, such as the electromagnetic force, strong force, and weak force.
